{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let there be 2 variables a and b where,
a=b
1. multiply a on both the sides,
a^{2}=ab
2. subtract b^2 on both the sides,
a^{2}-b^{2}=ab-b^{2}
3. since a^{2}-b^{2}=(a+b)(a-b),
(a+b)(a-b)=b(a-b)                         [taking b common]
4. dividing by (a-b) on both the sides, we get,
a+b=b
5. but a=b as given in the first step,
b+b=b
2b=b
6. dividing by b on both sides,
2=1
Which step did I make a mistake?"}]}]}

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"area[AEIG]=32-16=\boxed{16}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

The answer appears independent of the relative sizes, and taking the limit as each square approaches that of the middle settles that."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So, assume all squares are the same size.  Once done the red section becomes a parallelogram with base 4 and height 4.  Trivial isn't it?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let the bottom left hand corner of the middle sized square be at the origin of the Cartesian plane.
Let the big square have side length b and the small square have side length s.
Then it is easy to see that the coordinates of the required quadrilateral are in clockwise order, (-b,b),(0,4),(4+s,4-s) and (4,0)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Apply the marvellously simple "},{"type":"text","text":"shoelace formula","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":" to these coordinates to see the side lengths of the big and the small square vanish in a puff of logic leaving the answer 16."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Knowing that the red area doesnt change with the size of the adjacent squares. (Cant't because there is no information about them) Minimize the adjacent squares. Only the square in the middle is left.
"},{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/sig2EXMr6n-bild1.png?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Given that the question has an answer independent of the sizes of the larger or smaller squares, it suffices to calculate a numerical solution to one special case e.g. when all three squares are equal."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"It's plain to see that in such a case the quadrilateral is a parallelogram with area equal to the center square. Thus answer must be 16."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The problem statement learns us nothing about the size of the external squares.  The possible solutions are all integer.  Therefore I conclude that the solution is independent of the area of the external squares. (Which indeed has been proven in earlier solutions - it all cancels out).
So let us reconsider the problem with three equal squares:
"},{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/MzPzHbsPJh-2018-07-27_15-18-00.jpg?width=1200"}},{"type":"text","text":"
The red figure then simply becomes a parallellogram.  Its area is Base (4) * Height (4) = 16"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let the side length of the large square be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and that of the small square be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". We have no information about "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", they can have any value, yet the problem asks for a fixed solution. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So, the answer is independent of the values of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Let's look at the border case "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". In this case, all we have left is the center square, it coincides with the red area, which is 16."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/KSd1b9rZMg-4756e9bc28cbfe54c2d4333f3eccb3c270d61215.png?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What we know:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"codeBlock","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1) Triangles that have the same base and height are equal in area
2) The middle square (quadrilateral BCEF) = 16
"}],"attrs":[{"text":"1) Triangles that have the same base and height are equal in area
2) The middle square (quadrilateral BCEF) = 16
","language":null}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"According to 1), "},{"type":"text","text":"triangle ABF is equivalent to triangle AEF","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Both triangle ABF and triangle AEF include triangle AFG within themselves, therefore "},{"type":"text","text":"triangle ABG has an area equivalent to triangle EFG","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Similarly, "},{"type":"text","text":"triangle BCH has an area equivalent to triangle DEH","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"codeBlock","content":[{"type":"text","text":" triangle BCH and triangle EFG, and quadrilateral BHEG = quadrilateral BCEF and
 quadrilateral BCEF = 16 according to 2)
"}],"attrs":[{"text":" triangle BCH and triangle EFG, and quadrilateral BHEG = quadrilateral BCEF and
 quadrilateral BCEF = 16 according to 2)
","language":null}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"we can deduce that triangle ABG, triangle DEH, and quadrilateral BHEG (what we are looking for) has the same area as the Square in the middle; 16. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Sincere apologies to the color blind..."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This is not a rigorous solution!","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let the sides of the outer squares be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a \geq 4 \geq b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". The statement doesn't provide enough information to determine the value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and the answers suggest the result does not depend on "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" or "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If we choose convenient values for them (f.e. "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b=4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" or "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"), the red quadrilateral turns into a shape with known sides and whose area can be easily computed.
For "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" the red shape is a right triangle with sides "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"; its area is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{8 \times 4}{2} = 16"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"More intuition than math :
Let a be the length of the big square and b that of the small one. Since we have no information whatsover about a and b (and they can therefore be any size), let : 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a = 4 and b = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
Doing so we get 2 squares side by side (the little one disappears and the big one becomes the size of the medium one). We then have a red square triangle half the area of the 2 squares.
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"((4+4)*4)/2 = 16"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This may be cheating, somewhat, but based on the way the problem was worded, I inferred that it didn’t matter how large the other squares were, and the answer would be the same no matter what. Therefore, we can set the side lengths of both of the other squares to 4, giving us a parallelogram of height 4 and base 4, and an area of "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"table","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"tableRow","content":[{"type":"tableCell","content":[{"type":"text","text":"16"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The sizes of the larger and smaller squares are not given, the result is therefore invariant on these values."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let the larger  and smaller squares be of side length 4, In this case the required area constitutes a parallelogram of parallel side length 4 and height 4"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus area = 4 x 4 = 16"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The centre square is made up of a red band and two white triangles.
The big square on the left contains a red triangle."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Statement 1: The area of the red triangle in the big square is equal to the bottom white triangle in the centre square. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Statement 2: The red area to the right of the centre square is equal to the top white triangle in the centre square."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"It follows that the complete red area in the diagram is equal to the area of the centre square."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Proof of Statement 1:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let the side of the centre square be c, and the side of the left hand (big) square be b.
Consider the line from the top left corner of the big square to the bottom right corner of the centre square. This line intersects the vertical line common to the two squares. Let the distance from the bottom of the diagram to the intersection point be x."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Considering similar triangles: x = bc/(b + c). "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Area of the bottom white triangle = ½ cx = ½ bc^2/(b + c)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Area of left red triangle = ½ b(c – x) = ½ b(c – bc/(b + c)) = ½ b (c2^/(b + c))."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Statement 2 can be proved in a similar way."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore the red area is equal to the area of the centre square which is given as 16."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Somewhat cheating solution (assuming that there is an invariant answer instead of proving that it is invariant):"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The areas of the larger and smaller squares are not given, therefore we can assume that the answer does not depend on those sizes, and the area will remain the same if those sizes vary.  So we can set those areas to be 16 also, giving a vastly simplified parallellogram as the red area with base and height equal to the middle square.  Thus the area is 16."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{cases}
100a+b =c^n\\
10b+a=d^n\\
gcd(c,d)=1?
\end{cases}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Details and assumptions","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"There are no restrictions on the values of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]}]}

"},{"type":"orderedList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"There exist integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a,b,c,d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(c,d) = 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100a + b = c^n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10b + a = d^n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"There exists an integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"u"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"u^n \,\equiv \, 10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" modulo "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"999"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"There exists an integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"v"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"v^n \,\equiv \, 100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" modulo "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"999"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If Condition (1) is true, then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10c^n - d^n = 999a \,\equiv\, 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" modulo "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"999"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(c,999) > 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be a common prime factor of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"999"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (either "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" or "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"37"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"). Then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" also divides "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d^n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and hence "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" divides "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are not coprime. Thus we deduce that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"999"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are coprime, so there exists an integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"e"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ce \, \equiv\, 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" modulo "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"999"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(de)^n \,\equiv\,10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" modulo "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"999"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Hence Condition (2) is true."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If Condition (2) is true, so that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"u^n \equiv 10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" modulo "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"999"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for some "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"u"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(u^2)^n \,=\, (u^n)^2 \,\equiv\, 100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" modulo "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"999"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and hence Condition (3) is true."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If Condition (3) is true, so that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"v^n \equiv 100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" modulo "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"999"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for some "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"v"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", put "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c=v"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d=1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Certainly "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are coprime. Then
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{array}{rcl}
10c^n - d^n & = & 10v^n - 1 \; \equiv \; 10\times100 - 1 \; \equiv \; 0 \\
100d^n - c^n & = & 100 - v^n \; \equiv \; 0
\end{array} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
modulo "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"999"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and hence we can find integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a,b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 10c^n - d^n \; = \; 999a \qquad 100d^n - c^n \; = \; 999b "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Thus
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{array}{rcl}
999(100a + b) & = & 100(10c^n - d^n) + (100d^n - c^n) \; = \; 999c^n \\
999(10b + a) & = & 10(100d^n - c^n) + 10c^n - d^n \; = \; 999d^n
\end{array} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
so that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100a+b = c^n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10b+a = d^n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and Condition (1) is satisfied."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10^3 \,=\, 1000 \,\equiv\, 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" modulo "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"999"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we see that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10^{3a+1} \,\equiv\,10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for all "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a \ge 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and hence Condition (2) is satisfied for all integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n \equiv 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" modulo "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Also "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10^{3a+2} \,\equiv\, 100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for all "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a \ge 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and hence Condition (3) is satisfied for all integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n \equiv 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" modulo "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"625^3 \,\equiv\, 10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" modulo "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"999"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (thank you, Excel!), we deduce that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"625^{9a+3} \,\equiv\, 10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"625^{9a+6} \,\equiv\, 100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" modulo "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"999"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and so Conditions (2) and (3) are satisfied for all integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n \equiv 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n \equiv 6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" modulo "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" respectively."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So far, we have shown that Condition (1) holds for all integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" except multiples of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". I claim that Condition (1) does not hold if "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a multiple of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Suppose that Condition (1) held for some "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n = 9a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Then we can find an integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"u"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"u^{9a} \equiv 10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" modulo "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"999"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". This would imply that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(u^a)^9 \equiv 10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" modulo "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"999"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and hence that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"v^9 \equiv 10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" modulo "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"999"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for some integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"v"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". But (thank you, Excel, again) we can easily check that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is not a ninth power modulo "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"999"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus we deduce that Condition (1) holds precisely for those integers which are not multiples of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". There are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"111"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" multiples of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" between "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"999"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and hence there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"888"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" between "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"999"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" inclusive for which Condition (1) holds."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
